title: The Big Mistake: Three
body:
Pairing: Chris Evans/OFC

Summary: Frankie the Imposter has been in Robert Downey Jnr’s innercircle for years. She has watched Chris morph into a superstar from the sidelines, pining. One night leads the pair down a road untravelled and shakes their friendship to the core.

Warnings: Smut, Language, Unplanned Pregnancy

A/N: I haven’t written in nearly 15 years so please be gentle!

2011

Robert was a boisterous and vivacious host. His personality was a complex mix of calming and chaotic. He was a showman.

Marvel were knee-deep in the trenches of The Avengers filming. Frankie was exhausted, but she knew better than to turn down an invitation to a Downey Jnr barbeque. The finance department were down three key analysts and five junior staff due to the flu.

With a cold beer in her hands and the hot sun on her shoulders, she watched over the small group of toddlers playing happily in the shaded ball pit.

Charlie, Robert’s youngest, babbled happily at her whilst climbing into her lap, nearly causing her to spill her drink.

“Here let me help you,” a deep voice chuckled to her right and someone grabbed her beer.

“Thankyou,” she said after securing Charlie in her lap and looked up at her hero. Captain America. He was even more beautiful in person.

“I think you’re a bit young to be spilling drinks Charlie-bear.” He sat in the chair beside her and started to coo over Charlie. “I’m Chris.”

“Frankie,” she said shyly.

****

The first thing that alerted Frankie to the new day was a strange wet sensation on her cheek. Is my roof leaking again? She cracked open one eye to see a brown and white furry face staring at her and blinding light. “Dodger?” Her voice was weak and rough. This was going to be one hell of a hangover. She sat up a little and took in her surroundings. Why am I naked in Chris’ bedroom?

“Morning,” an equally rough voice captured her attention and she looked to Chris leaning against the doorway of his bathroom, towelling his hair. He looked so sheepish.

Frankie pulled the sheet tighter against herself, feeling very vulnerable and confused. Dodger pushed his nose against her demanding attention. “Did we…” She couldn’t bring herself to finish the question.

“Yeah.” His face was a parade of regret and embarrassment.

Frankie was at a loss for words. The air was rife with tension. He pushed off the doorframe and came to sit next to her, running his hands through Dodger’s fur.

“I’m really sorry, Frankie. I never meant for this to happen.”

Of course you didn’t. Why would you want to sleep with your fat friend? His rejection burnt deep.

His eyes searched her face, trying to read her. “I really don’t want to do this,” he continued and Frankie had to fight to breath, “but I have a breakfast date…” White noise rang through her ears, drowning out his monologue.

“I’ll get out your hair,” she said in a voice so small he barely heard her.

“Please Frankie,” he pleaded reaching out to her retreating body.

“It’s fine,” she said putting on a brave face, betrayed by tears falling down her face, “I hope your date goes well. I can let myself out.”

Chris wanted to go after her but deep down he knew it would only escalate the situation. Or are you just being a big coward, Chris?

Back in the safety of her own home Frankie broke down and sobbed.

You really are a fuck up Francesca Anne Taylor.

****

Frankie wallowed in self-pity, Ben and Jerry’s and tequila for a week before picking herself back up and throwing herself into work. Her dreams were haunted by flashes of that night. It had been damn good.

Two weeks post epic-wedding fuckup she was starting to hate herself a little bit less. That was until she arrived at her desk to find a very large bouquet of sunflowers on her desk. Her heart stopped as she read the attached card.

I’m sorry, I’m an asshole. Chris x

The floodgates collapsed and Frankie crawled under desk to break down.

****

Frankie knew coming to this dinner party was a bad idea but she knew deep down that if she missed Chris’ birthday party their friends would ask questions. Her plan was to sit at the furthest end of the table away from him so not to raise suspicion. She was sat with Sebastian and Anthony whose constant bantering kept her distracted. Well mostly.

She dared to sneak a look up at the head of the table. He looked handsome and more at ease than he had looked in months. His plump lips, red from his wine, spread into a smile. The same lips that had explored her body that night.

He pulls his lips from her ear lobe and begins to make their descent down her body. He takes her nipple in his mouth as she ruts into him hard, sweet moans escaping her lips.

“If I had known you sounded so pretty I wouldn’t have waited to so long.”

When she felt heated cobalt eyes meet hers she blushed furiously and looked to Sebastian.

I shouldn’t be here. I don’t belong here.

“Is everything alright, pumpkin?” She turned to look at Robert, who whispered in her ear. “You look tired.”

You can’t tell him. Chris is his friend. “Work is busy. Sweeney Todd opens in a month and they’re still calling for budget cuts. I’m pretty sure the costume department hate me,” she chuckled and picked up her glass of water.

“Are you sure it has nothing to do with you and Evans getting chummy at the wedding?” Frankie nearly spat her water and started to cough, drawing attention from their fellow guests.

“Excuse me?” her voice hushed. “I was his sympathy date because I had no one else to go with and he didn’t want to look like a loser. Besides, I think he has much better taste in women.”

Robert knew he was pushing her buttons, but he smirked and pressed on, desperate to get to the bottom of her attitude. “So there was no hanky panky? You didn’t get to ride the shield?”

Frankie burnt with embarrassment. “Fuck off Robert,” and she stormed off to the bathroom, a few eyes following her.

Safely away from everyone she splashed cool water onto her face. Fuck Robert Downey Jnr and his stupid powers of perception. She held onto the sink and bowed her head. Just go out there you coward, put on your big girl panties and don’t make this about you.

Before she could enter the private dining room she collided with a large body.

Chris smiled shyly, helping her catch her balance. “I’m sorry I wasn’t watching where I was going.” His hands were hot against her bare arms.

His hands held her face against his, his tongue battling against hers as he fucked her into the bed.

Frankie could barely make eye contact. “No I’m sorry, it’s my fault.”

He sighed and noted her closed-off body language. “How are you?”

I slept with my friend and I hate myself for it. “Okay. You?” He shrugged. “Thank you for the flowers, they were beautiful. I’m sorry I didn’t text…” she sighed, “I’m a coward.”

“I should have called. I felt terrible for basically kicking you out,” he began but stopped as she stepped back and closed in on herself, tears threatening to escape.

“It’s fine. Really. You should go back to your guests. Happy birthday.” He watched her retreat back into the private room and sit next to Robert, pulling him into a tight hug and whisper something in his ear.

“You alright buddy?” He turned to see Anthony exiting the bathroom. “You look a little, I dunno, tired.”

“Yeah I’m good, just a lot on my mind with having to go back to Washington,” Chris lied watching Frankie converse with Sebastian. She looked dejected under that mask he knew she wore. Not that he could blame her. You only have yourself to blame, Chris.

title: Too Tired
body:
About: As requested by @i-padfootblack-things, Chris and the reader have a door-slamming, voice-raising, tear-filled kind of fight which ends with sleeping in separate rooms. Well, trying to. After realizing he can’t sleep without her, Chris decides making up would be better than spending the night alone.

Word Count: 3,355

Warnings: fighting, language, you know the drill

A/N: Thank you so much for this request! I really enjoyed writing it and I think it shows. Thanks for your patience too- I feel like this one took me forever, but I hope it was worth the wait :) Please feel free to send any other requests, they’re a great inspiration when I’m feeling a bit stuck. Enjoy!

“I don’t know why you always have to do this right before bed,” Chris sighed, pinching his nose right beneath his furrowed eyebrows. From where I sat in our bed, under the covers, in my pajamas, and not necessarily ready to go to sleep with our issue pressing on my mind, now seemed like the perfect time.

Chris was quiet for a moment as I heard the tap water run for a moment before it was replaced with the buzzing of his electric toothbrush. He leaned against the doorframe and I really wished I wasn’t so mad at him. With only his checkered pajama bottoms on, I couldn’t help thinking about how I’d like those off too. Plus, I’d missed him so much while Chris was away filming for the past few months. Especially after such a frustrating day, it was tempting to just say fuck it and cuddle up next to him.

Chris raised his eyebrows as if to say, “Well?” as a drop of toothpaste started dribbling down his chin. I rolled my eyes, fluffing my pillow a little too harshly in an attempt to avoid the conversation I’d initiated, but it was obvious to both of us that a hard pillow wasn’t what was making me uncomfortable.

“I don’t like going to bed mad at you,” I huffed quietly. Whether it was because Chris didn’t know what to say or he couldn’t respond amidst all the toothpaste foam, he didn’t acknowledge what I’d said. So I kept talking. “I just don’t think you needed a boys night,” I said, trying to not sound as dejected as I felt. Even I knew that was only the tip of the iceberg.

Chris rolled his eyes pointedly before ducking into the bathroom. I heard the water run again as he spit, dreading when the tap turned off. He came out with his arms crossed, accentuating his taught biceps. It really wasn’t fair Chris seemed to be even less resistible when I was angry with him. One of his eyebrows hung a little lower than the other as Chris looked at me with a concentrated irritation and his mouth dangled open just enough to notice. “Really?” he asked in a tone that simply screamed he thought I was being ridiculous to be this upset about such a thing.

Although it was rhetorical, I answered anyway. “Yes,” I shot back, crossing my own arms to show I was just as capable of sticking to my guns. Chris did this thing where he’d make me feel irrational for being upset about something so trivial every time we argued. I don’t think he meant to be so high and mighty, but being belittled was so frustrating when all I wanted was for him to take my feelings seriously.

“I only went out for a beer with the boys. Sorry, I came home later than I said, sue me,” Chris said with a shrug, puffing out his bottom lip in an attempt to be nonchalant. I wasn’t going to let him brush it off that easy. “It’s not about that, Chris,” I sighed as my shoulders slumped, so defeated before the battle really began. I wished he could just know how I feel and why without these arguments that boil over into bigger fights so easily.

I was tired of it. Of all of the days spent without him while Chris was across the country working, all of the arguments we had over Skype, and the fights stemming from unresolved issues when he was finally home. I was tired of explaining myself to someone who made no attempts to understand.

“It’s just-” I started anyway, my tone a little too shrill. Chris raised his eyebrows with a teasing encouragement as if he couldn’t wait to see what came out of my mouth next. He stayed planted by the bathroom door, like a tree that would stubbornly stand tall in the face of a storm. Like a guy who would rather stand there than climb into bed next to me.

I cleared my throat and tried again, more conscious of the lump inside of it than ever. “I rarely see you with how often you’ve been working lately. And when you’re here, you’re barely even home,” I concluded when my voice cracked. I wasn’t going to cry- at least that’s what I kept telling myself.

Chris’s lips turned up in a smirk which felt more like a punch in the stomach. “I’m so sorry that I want to see my friends,” he said sarcastically. I tried to breathe deeply, suppressing my desperate need to snap at him. If I was going to ask him to be more considerate, the least I could do was offer him the same. But he made that a hell of a lot easier said than done sometimes. 

“You know that isn’t what I mean,” I spoke through gritted teeth. Chris could tell he was really bothering me now, but that didn’t stop him. “What is it then, huh?” he pressed. Chris put his hands on his hips and let his face adopt a look of concern as he feigned curiosity.

I didn’t respond, which wasn’t because I didn’t have anything to say to something so inane. I just had better things to focus on like holding in my tears, but Chris took it as an opportunity to keep pressing my buttons.  “You can’t hold my work schedule against me. I told you I wouldn’t be around and you signed up for this anyway,” he reminded me as if that solved our problems. As if the fact that he was already some big famous actor when we met, something our entire relationship was built to cope with, could just casually slip my mind. As if I would laugh it off and say, “Oh, yeah. Sorry, my bad.”

Instead, I stared at him with tears welling up in my eyes. My bottom lip trembled as I tried to hold it together. Angry crying was the most aggravating thing. Chris always came back down to earth to comfort me and I felt guilty for some reason and our problem never got resolved since the fight was put on hold. I refused to let that happen this time. I tried to swallow the lump in my throat, which was growing into more of a boulder now. “That isn’t what this is about Chris,” I said lowly. I tried to sound stern, but it came out more like a plea.

Chris buried his face in his hands, his chest rising with each deep breath. “Well, you aren’t exactly telling me,” he huffed with frustration. When he lifted his head, he looked absolutely done. His words hung in the thick air between us for a while, neither of us accepting defeat. I always struggled with finding the right words, especially when I was so upset. As exasperating as it was to feel like Chris didn’t understand me, he was right to say I didn’t explain myself well.

“Look, if you’re upset because I went out with my friends instead of staying here with you, I’m not going to apologize for that,” Chris finally said indignantly. I just looked at him with my mouth opening and closing like a fish out of water, knowing that if I spoke I would erupt into tears.

That only seemed to make Chris angrier. “Dammit!” he shouted, facing the wall instead of me. He slammed a hand against the wall, causing me to jump while the picture frames shook on their hooks. “It’s not fair of you to bring up some fucking issue you have without even being able to say shit about it, you know that? I’m not a mind reader,” Chris yelled, whipping around to face me. His blue eyes were wide and full of emotion, trying to convey all of the feelings his words couldn’t.

Still, I sat on our bed unable to say a word, painfully aware of how small I felt under his angry gaze. Chris ran a hand through his hair, trying to collect himself. He turned to face the wall again as if he couldn’t even stand to look at me, but he spun again to look at me as he said, “I don’t know what your problem is.” Chris’s nostrils flared as his voice started to rise again.

“Is it that seeing other people makes you feel like you aren’t enough for me? Or maybe it’s because I have better things to do than tend to your every beck and call? I hate to break it to you darling, but you aren’t the center of my entire fucking universe.” Chris spoke with a resigned certainty as he spit the kind of words that hit you right where it hurts, the kind of hurt you don’t forget. I knew I’d always have that wildly vexed look in his eye, the way he sounded so dissatisfied with me, and the feeling of my heart dropping burned into my memory. I was my closest to crying then as the tears brimmed my eyes and threatened to fall despite my best efforts, but I refused to give Chris the satisfaction of knowing he’d gotten to me.

It seemed Chris immediately regretted the words even as they left his lips. The vein bulging on his forehead seemed to fade away again as he took a few deep breaths, grappling to get back the temper he’d lost. Chris averted his eyes to the floor, running a hand through his messy hair. This time, when he turned to the wall because he couldn’t look at me, I knew it wasn’t because he was angry. Chris was guilty. “I just want to go to bed,” he finally said, sounding so ragged I almost wanted to drop it. Still, he didn’t make a move toward our bed.

But I knew if we did, it would be even more of a fight next time I was bothered enough to bring it up. “I want to fix this,” I challenged, gesturing to the space between us. It was only a few feet, but it felt like he was on Jupiter. I wanted Chris to sit down next to me and crack his knuckles, saying something about how we’d have to get on with that then so we could both just be happy. Instead, he pinched the bridge of his nose again.

“I’m tired,” Chris sighed, making his choice. I hated wondering if he intended it in the sleepy kind of way or if he meant he was tired of me. Maybe bringing this up when he was tired and toeing the line between tipsy and drunk wasn’t the best idea. Regardless, I couldn’t stand being around him any longer. I stood quickly, snatching my pillow and a throw blanket before Chris could even process the fact that I’d rather sleep on the couch than in the same room as him. “All yours,” I spit at him as I slammed the door behind me, hating myself for hoping he’d feel half as alone as I did.

I didn’t allow myself to let out all of my pent up emotion until I was in the living room and even then I prayed it was far enough from our bedroom that Chris couldn’t hear how I screamed into a pillow, suddenly filled with more rage than anything. I was too mad to even cry. Mad at Chris and myself and the situation. I fell back on the couch, hoping I could go to sleep and forget about everything for at least a few hours, but I had no such luck.

Even as emotionally exhausted as I was, it seemed all I could do was stare at the ceiling. It felt wrong to fall asleep without the familiar feeling of Chris pressed against my back, our legs entwined. I could tell when he fell asleep when his breaths which always tickled my ear grew slower and softer. Knowing Chris was peacefully resting made it easier for me to sleep. How he always smelled, like clean laundry and a fresh shower and something else I could only describe as Chris, didn’t hurt either. I laid there for hours, tossing and turning just like I did every night he was gone.

My ears perked up when I heard a door creak open from far away. In the quiet night, the feet padding down, slow with hesitation before gaining a sure speed, resonated through the otherwise empty house. My heart dropped as dealing with all of this became even more impending, but I couldn’t ignore the butterflies that exploded in my stomach simultaneously.

I sat up when I heard the footsteps stop. Chris stood before me, rubbing his bicep nervously. His hair was in disarray like he’d been running his hands through it more times than I could count. He had red, puffy eyes and tear-stained cheeks, which only made him look even more like a little boy who’d stumbled into his parents’ room after a nightmare. It broke my heart to know I’d had a hand in this.

Chris started to speak, but his voice cracked so painfully he stopped to compose himself. Before he could try again and I could think about it, I stood and wrapped my arms around him so tightly I thought I’d never be able to untangle myself from him. I didn’t want to, either. Every concern about maintaining my pride or how angry I was fled my mind. I knew none of that mattered. At the end of the day, we just knew we needed each other.

It wasn’t long before strong arms enveloped me, pulling my body into a familiar chest as I was wracked with sobs that finally escaped. It was like a dam broke, tears I’d been holding in for so long just poured out of me in a massive wave. Chris took a seat on the couch and guided me with him, shushing me quietly while holding me tight. I sat in his lap, crying so hard I started to hiccup and hyperventilate. Chris only hugged me tighter, telling me to focus on his heartbeat and breathe with him. I tried and failed and finally, he just peppered the top of my head with gentle kisses and whispered apologies until I ran out of tears.

“Why are you here?” I said quietly with an unsteady voice, careful not to speak too loudly in the dead of night. I don’t know who I was nervous to disturb, it was just the two of us. The way it was supposed to be. Chris shrugged his strong shoulders, looking up at me through his dark lashes as he slumped into the couch. “Couldn’t sleep without you,” he whispered back to me like it was a secret only we could know. A silence stretched between us after that, neither of us too sure of what to say or where to start.

“I shouldn’t have said that. I was way out of line,” Chris said before pressing a long kiss to my forehead once I could catch my breath. I couldn’t care about keeping up appearances anymore, we needed to be real with each other and actually talk this out. I tucked my head into the crook of Chris’s neck, allowing myself to melt into his warmth.  “It was so wrong,” I reiterated, my voice still shaking. Chris’s chest shook with his chuckle, the deep vibration bringing me a comfort that was almost jarring. “So wrong,” he repeated, rubbing calming circles on the small of my back.

“I just have a hard time understanding you sometimes,” he continued slowly, careful to choose the right words before concluding, “then I get upset with myself for it, but I shouldn’t take that out on you.”

“It’s not your fault,” I reassured him, wiping the tears from under my chin. I re-positioned myself so I was facing Chris now. The pained look on his face made this more difficult, but there was something so entrancing about how the moonlight coming through the window played with the structured lines of his face. Chris looked soft and pretty, a welcomed contrast to the angry red he’d been earlier. He looked like the Chris I knew and loved. “I’m going to try to communicate better instead of shutting down,” I promised. Chris gave me a tight-lipped smile as he caressed my face, wiping my tears.

“Tell me what’s really been on your mind,” Chris whispered like he was testing the waters with more of an invitation than a demand. I swallowed my reservations, knowing that this was a safer space than the argument we’d had before. Chris was genuinely all ears, I could tell by the patience he exuded.

“You know I love how much you love your work,” I said as I looked him right in the eye, hoping he understood how honest I was. “And I love your friends, too. I love that you have these things that make you so happy… I don’t have a problem sharing you,” I continued, averting my eyes to where my hands sat wringing in my lap.

Chris took notice and held my hands in his, rubbing small circles with his thumbs on my palms. I sighed, knowing he was trying to be understanding, but that meant I had to allow him to be. “I just miss you so much when you’re away and even when you’re here it’s like you aren’t really with me.”

Tears started slipping down my cheeks again. I watched as they dripped down my chin and fell on our hands. “I-I feel like you don’t want to be,” I confessed. Before I finished saying the words, Chris pulled me into another hug. My cheek pressed against his chest, the steady thump of his heart and its movement with each of his breaths bringing me comfort. It reminded me that he was here with me, grounding me back to Earth.

“No, no, no,” Chris whispered, the conviction still evident in his voice. “Couldn’t be farther from the truth,” he reassured me. “I’m sorry I made you feel like that… I didn’t even know you did.” Chris pulled away from the hug, holding me at arm’s length. He tilted my chin up so I looked at him and with the kind of intensity he had in his eyes it was hard to look away.

“I love you more than anything,” Chris declared like he was telling me the sun rises in the east and sets in the west, it was a fact of life. “It makes being away from you a hell of a lot harder than it’s ever been for me before. I guess I was trying to distance myself to make it easier when I’m gone,” Chris sighed, running his fingers through his hair again. “Clearly doesn’t work,” he chuckled. I laughed too, for what felt like the first time in way too long.

“I don’t like when we fight,” I told him, playing with his fingers until they became laced together with mine. “Gee, no ‘I love you too, light of my life?’” Chris poked fun at me. I rolled my eyes, but I wasn’t really annoyed, probably given away by my goofy grin. “You know I do,” I replied, leaning forward to place a kiss on his cheek, already itchy with stubble. When I pulled away, I saw Chris beaming at me with a smile from ear to ear and a light he’d lost before back in his eye. With a voice that was still raspy from his tiredness, Chris said, “I don’t like it either.”

He stood, pulling me by our locked-together hands so I’d follow him. Chris swung our arms between us as he looked down at me with a kindness I’d missed. “Why don’t we get some sleep?” he prompted, tugging us toward the hallway. I walked a little faster so our steps would be in sync, allowing me to cuddle up against his side until we climbed into bed, where we finally fell asleep in each other’s arms.

It wasn’t long before strong arms enveloped me, pulling my body into a familiar chest as I was wracked with sobs that finally escaped. It was like a dam broke, tears I’d been holding in for so long just poured out of me in a massive wave. Chris took a seat on the couch and guided me with him, shushing me quietly while holding me tight. I sat in his lap, crying so hard I started to hiccup and hyperventilate. Chris only hugged me tighter, telling me to focus on his heartbeat and breathe with him. I tried and failed and finally, he just peppered the top of my head with gentle kisses and whispered apologies until I ran out of tears.

“Why are you here?” I said quietly with an unsteady voice, careful not to speak too loudly in the dead of night. I don’t know who I was nervous to disturb, it was just the two of us. The way it was supposed to be. Chris shrugged his strong shoulders, looking up at me through his dark lashes as he slumped into the couch. “Couldn’t sleep without you,” he whispered back to me like it was a secret only we could know. A silence stretched between us after that, neither of us too sure of what to say or where to start.

“I shouldn’t have said that. I was way out of line,” Chris said before pressing a long kiss to my forehead once I could catch my breath. I couldn’t care about keeping up appearances anymore, we needed to be real with each other and actually talk this out. I tucked my head into the crook of Chris’s neck, allowing myself to melt into his warmth.  “It was so wrong,” I reiterated, my voice still shaking. Chris’s chest shook with his chuckle, the deep vibration bringing me a comfort that was almost jarring. “So wrong,” he repeated, rubbing calming circles on the small of my back.

“I just have a hard time understanding you sometimes,” he continued slowly, careful to choose the right words before concluding, “then I get upset with myself for it, but I shouldn’t take that out on you.”

“It’s not your fault,” I reassured him, wiping the tears from under my chin. I re-positioned myself so I was facing Chris now. The pained look on his face made this more difficult, but there was something so entrancing about how the moonlight coming through the window played with the structured lines of his face. Chris looked soft and pretty, a welcomed contrast to the angry red he’d been earlier. He looked like the Chris I knew and loved. “I’m going to try to communicate better instead of shutting down,” I promised. Chris gave me a tight-lipped smile as he caressed my face, wiping my tears.

“Tell me what’s really been on your mind,” Chris whispered like he was testing the waters with more of an invitation than a demand. I swallowed my reservations, knowing that this was a safer space than the argument we’d had before. Chris was genuinely all ears, I could tell by the patience he exuded.

“You know I love how much you love your work,” I said as I looked him right in the eye, hoping he understood how honest I was. “And I love your friends, too. I love that you have these things that make you so happy… I don’t have a problem sharing you,” I continued, averting my eyes to where my hands sat wringing in my lap.

Chris took notice and held my hands in his, rubbing small circles with his thumbs on my palms. I sighed, knowing he was trying to be understanding, but that meant I had to allow him to be. “I just miss you so much when you’re away and even when you’re here it’s like you aren’t really with me.”

Chris swung our arms between us as he looked down at me with a kindness I’d missed. “Why don’t we get some sleep?” he prompted, tugging us toward the hallway. Warnings: fighting, language, you know the drill

[[MORE]]

“I don’t know why you always have to do this right before bed,” Chris sighed, pinching his nose right beneath his furrowed eyebrows. From where I sat in our bed, under the covers, in my pajamas, and not necessarily ready to go to sleep with our issue pressing on my mind, now seemed like the perfect time.

Chris was quiet for a moment as I heard the tap water run for a moment before it was replaced with the buzzing of his electric toothbrush. He leaned against the doorframe and I really wished I wasn’t so mad at him. With only his checkered pajama bottoms on, I couldn’t help thinking about how I’d like those off too. Plus, I’d missed him so much while Chris was away filming for the past few months. Especially after such a frustrating day, it was tempting to just say fuck it and cuddle up next to him.

Chris raised his eyebrows as if to say, “Well?” as a drop of toothpaste started dribbling down his chin. I rolled my eyes, fluffing my pillow a little too harshly in an attempt to avoid the conversation I’d initiated, but it was obvious to both of us that a hard pillow wasn’t what was making me uncomfortable.

“I don’t like going to bed mad at you,” I huffed quietly. Whether it was because Chris didn’t know what to say or he couldn’t respond amidst all the toothpaste foam, he didn’t acknowledge what I’d said. So I kept talking. “I just don’t think you needed a boys night,” I said, trying to not sound as dejected as I felt. Even I knew that was only the tip of the iceberg.

Chris rolled his eyes pointedly before ducking into the bathroom. I heard the water run again as he spit, dreading when the tap turned off. He came out with his arms crossed, accentuating his taught biceps. It really wasn’t fair Chris seemed to be even less resistible when I was angry with him. One of his eyebrows hung a little lower than the other as Chris looked at me with a concentrated irritation and his mouth dangled open just enough to notice. “Really?” he asked in a tone that simply screamed he thought I was being ridiculous to be this upset about such a thing.

Although it was rhetorical, I answered anyway. “Yes,” I shot back, crossing my own arms to show I was just as capable of sticking to my guns. Chris did this thing where he’d make me feel irrational for being upset about something so trivial every time we argued. I don’t think he meant to be so high and mighty, but being belittled was so frustrating when all I wanted was for him to take my feelings seriously.

“I only went out for a beer with the boys. Sorry, I came home later than I said, sue me,” Chris said with a shrug, puffing out his bottom lip in an attempt to be nonchalant. I wasn’t going to let him brush it off that easy. “It’s not about that, Chris,” I sighed as my shoulders slumped, so defeated before the battle really began. I wished he could just know how I feel and why without these arguments that boil over into bigger fights so easily.

I was tired of it. Of all of the days spent without him while Chris was across the country working, all of the arguments we had over Skype, and the fights stemming from unresolved issues when he was finally home. I was tired of explaining myself to someone who made no attempts to understand.

“It’s just-” I started anyway, my tone a little too shrill. Chris raised his eyebrows with a teasing encouragement as if he couldn’t wait to see what came out of my mouth next. He stayed planted by the bathroom door, like a tree that would stubbornly stand tall in the face of a storm. Like a guy who would rather stand there than climb into bed next to me.

I cleared my throat and tried again, more conscious of the lump inside of it than ever. “I rarely see you with how often you’ve been working lately. And when you’re here, you’re barely even home,” I concluded when my voice cracked. I wasn’t going to cry- at least that’s what I kept telling myself.

Chris’s lips turned up in a smirk which felt more like a punch in the stomach. “I’m so sorry that I want to see my friends,” he said sarcastically. I tried to breathe deeply, suppressing my desperate need to snap at him. If I was going to ask him to be more considerate, the least I could do was offer him the same. But he made that a hell of a lot easier said than done sometimes. 

“You know that isn’t what I mean,” I spoke through gritted teeth. Chris could tell he was really bothering me now, but that didn’t stop him. “What is it then, huh?” he pressed. Chris put his hands on his hips and let his face adopt a look of concern as he feigned curiosity.

I didn’t respond, which wasn’t because I didn’t have anything to say to something so inane. I just had better things to focus on like holding in my tears, but Chris took it as an opportunity to keep pressing my buttons.  “You can’t hold my work schedule against me. I told you I wouldn’t be around and you signed up for this anyway,” he reminded me as if that solved our problems. As if the fact that he was already some big famous actor when we met, something our entire relationship was built to cope with, could just casually slip my mind. As if I would laugh it off and say, “Oh, yeah. Sorry, my bad.”

Instead, I stared at him with tears welling up in my eyes. My bottom lip trembled as I tried to hold it together. Angry crying was the most aggravating thing. Chris always came back down to earth to comfort me and I felt guilty for some reason and our problem never got resolved since the fight was put on hold. I refused to let that happen this time. I tried to swallow the lump in my throat, which was growing into more of a boulder now. “That isn’t what this is about Chris,” I said lowly. I tried to sound stern, but it came out more like a plea.

Chris buried his face in his hands, his chest rising with each deep breath. “Well, you aren’t exactly telling me,” he huffed with frustration. When he lifted his head, he looked absolutely done. His words hung in the thick air between us for a while, neither of us accepting defeat. I always struggled with finding the right words, especially when I was so upset. As exasperating as it was to feel like Chris didn’t understand me, he was right to say I didn’t explain myself well.

“Look, if you’re upset because I went out with my friends instead of staying here with you, I’m not going to apologize for that,” Chris finally said indignantly. I just looked at him with my mouth opening and closing like a fish out of water, knowing that if I spoke I would erupt into tears.

He turned to face the wall again as if he couldn’t even stand to look at me, but he spun again to look at me as he said, “I don’t know what your problem is.” Chris’s nostrils flared as his voice started to rise again.

“Is it that seeing other people makes you feel like you aren’t enough for me? Or maybe it’s because I have better things to do than tend to your every beck and call? I knew I’d always have that wildly vexed look in his eye, the way he sounded so dissatisfied with me, and the feeling of my heart dropping burned into my memory. I was my closest to crying then as the tears brimmed my eyes and threatened to fall despite my best efforts, but I refused to give Chris the satisfaction of knowing he’d gotten to me.

The vein bulging on his forehead seemed to fade away again as he took a few deep breaths, grappling to get back the temper he’d lost. Chris averted his eyes to the floor, running a hand through his messy hair. This time, when he turned to the wall because he couldn’t look at me, I knew it wasn’t because he was angry. Chris was guilty. “I just want to go to bed,” he finally said, sounding so ragged I almost wanted to drop it. Still, he didn’t make a move toward our bed.

But I knew if we did, it would be even more of a fight next time I was bothered enough to bring it up. “I want to fix this,” I challenged, gesturing to the space between us. It was only a few feet, but it felt like he was on Jupiter. I wanted Chris to sit down next to me and crack his knuckles, saying something about how we’d have to get on with that then so we could both just be happy. Instead, he pinched the bridge of his nose again.

“I’m tired,” Chris sighed, making his choice. I hated wondering if he intended it in the sleepy kind of way or if he meant he was tired of me. Maybe bringing this up when he was tired and toeing the line between tipsy and drunk wasn’t the best idea. Regardless, I couldn’t stand being around him any longer. I stood quickly, snatching my pillow and a throw blanket before Chris could even process the fact that I’d rather sleep on the couch than in the same room as him. “All yours,” I spit at him as I slammed the door behind me, hating myself for hoping he’d feel half as alone as I did.

I didn’t allow myself to let out all of my pent up emotion until I was in the living room and even then I prayed it was far enough from our bedroom that Chris couldn’t hear how I screamed into a pillow, suddenly filled with more rage than anything. I was too mad to even cry. Mad at Chris and myself and the situation. I fell back on the couch, hoping I could go to sleep and forget about everything for at least a few hours, but I had no such luck.

Even as emotionally exhausted as I was, it seemed all I could do was stare at the ceiling. It felt wrong to fall asleep without the familiar feeling of Chris pressed against my back, our legs entwined. I could tell when he fell asleep when his breaths which always tickled my ear grew slower and softer. Knowing Chris was peacefully resting made it easier for me to sleep. How he always smelled, like clean laundry and a fresh shower and something else I could only describe as Chris, didn’t hurt either. I laid there for hours, tossing and turning just like I did every night he was gone.

My ears perked up when I heard a door creak open from far away. In the quiet night, the feet padding down, slow with hesitation before gaining a sure speed, resonated through the otherwise empty house. My heart dropped as dealing with all of this became even more impending, but I couldn’t ignore the butterflies that exploded in my stomach simultaneously.

I sat up when I heard the footsteps stop. Chris stood before me, rubbing his bicep nervously. His hair was in disarray like he’d been running his hands through it more times than I could count. He had red, puffy eyes and tear-stained cheeks, which only made him look even more like a little boy who’d stumbled into his parents’ room after a nightmare. It broke my heart to know I’d had a hand in this.

Chris started to speak, but his voice cracked so painfully he stopped to compose himself. I hate to break it to you darling, but you aren’t the center of my entire fucking universe.” Chris spoke with a resigned certainty as he spit the kind of words that hit you right where it hurts, the kind of hurt you don’t forget. I knew I’d always have that wildly vexed look in his eye, the way he sounded so dissatisfied with me, and the feeling of my heart dropping burned into my memory. I was my closest to crying then as the tears brimmed my eyes and threatened to fall despite my best efforts, but I refused to give Chris the satisfaction of knowing he’d gotten to me.

It seemed Chris immediately regretted the words even as they left his lips. The vein bulging on his forehead seemed to fade away again as he took a few deep breaths, grappling to get back the temper he’d lost. Chris averted his eyes to the floor, running a hand through his messy hair. This time, when he turned to the wall because he couldn’t look at me, I knew it wasn’t because he was angry. Chris was guilty. “I just want to go to bed,” he finally said, sounding so ragged I almost wanted to drop it. Still, he didn’t make a move toward our bed.

But I knew if we did, it would be even more of a fight next time I was bothered enough to bring it up. “I want to fix this,” I challenged, gesturing to the space between us. It was only a few feet, but it felt like he was on Jupiter. I wanted Chris to sit down next to me and crack his knuckles, saying something about how we’d have to get on with that then so we could both just be happy. Instead, he pinched the bridge of his nose again.

“I’m tired,” Chris sighed, making his choice. I hated wondering if he intended it in the sleepy kind of way or if he meant he was tired of me. Maybe bringing this up when he was tired and toeing the line between tipsy and drunk wasn’t the best idea. Regardless, I couldn’t stand being around him any longer. I stood quickly, snatching my pillow and a throw blanket before Chris could even process the fact that I’d rather sleep on the couch than in the same room as him. “All yours,” I spit at him as I slammed the door behind me, hating myself for hoping he’d feel half as alone as I did.

I didn’t allow myself to let out all of my pent up emotion until I was in the living room and even then I prayed it was far enough from our bedroom that Chris couldn’t hear how I screamed into a pillow, suddenly filled with more rage than anything. I was too mad to even cry. Mad at Chris and myself and the situation. I fell back on the couch, hoping I could go to sleep and forget about everything for at least a few hours, but I had no such luck.

Even as emotionally exhausted as I was, it seemed all I could do was stare at the ceiling. It felt wrong to fall asleep without the familiar feeling of Chris pressed against my back, our legs entwined. I could tell when he fell asleep when his breaths which always tickled my ear grew slower and softer. Knowing Chris was peacefully resting made it easier for me to sleep. How he always smelled, like clean laundry and a fresh shower and something else I could only describe as Chris, didn’t hurt either. I laid there for hours, tossing and turning just like I did every night he was gone.

My ears perked up when I heard a door creak open from far away. In the quiet night, the feet padding down, slow with hesitation before gaining a sure speed, resonated through the otherwise empty house. My heart dropped as dealing with all of this became even more impending, but I couldn’t ignore the butterflies that exploded in my stomach simultaneously.

I sat up when I heard the footsteps stop. Chris stood before me, rubbing his bicep nervously. His hair was in disarray like he’d been running his hands through it more times than I could count. He had red, puffy eyes and tear-stained cheeks, which only made him look even more like a little boy who’d stumbled into his parents’ room after a nightmare. It broke my heart to know I’d had a hand in this.

Chris started to speak, but his voice cracked so painfully he stopped to compose himself. Before he could try again and I could think about it, I stood and wrapped my arms around him so tightly I thought I’d never be able to untangle myself from him. I didn’t want to, either. Every concern about maintaining my pride or how angry I was fled my mind. I knew none of that mattered. At the end of the day, we just knew we needed each other.

It wasn’t long before strong arms enveloped me, pulling my body into a familiar chest as I was wracked with sobs that finally escaped. It was like a dam broke, tears I’d been holding in for so long just poured out of me in a massive wave. Chris took a seat on the couch and guided me with him, shushing me quietly while holding me tight. I sat in his lap, crying so hard I started to hiccup and hyperventilate. Chris only hugged me tighter, telling me to focus on his heartbeat and breathe with him. I tried and failed and finally, he just peppered the top of my head with gentle kisses and whispered apologies until I ran out of tears.

“Why are you here?” I said quietly with an unsteady voice, careful not to speak too loudly in the dead of night. I don’t know who I was nervous to disturb, it was just the two of us. The way it was supposed to be. Chris shrugged his strong shoulders, looking up at me through his dark lashes as he slumped into the couch. “Couldn’t sleep without you,” he whispered back to me like it was a secret only we could know. A silence stretched between us after that, neither of us too sure of what to say or where to start.

“I shouldn’t have said that. I was way out of line,” Chris said before pressing a long kiss to my forehead once I could catch my breath. I couldn’t care about keeping up appearances anymore, we needed to be real with each other and actually talk this out. I tucked my head into the crook of Chris’s neck, allowing myself to melt into his warmth.  “It was so wrong,” I reiterated, my voice still shaking. Chris’s chest shook with his chuckle, the deep vibration bringing me a comfort that was almost jarring. “So wrong,” he repeated, rubbing calming circles on the small of my back.

“I just have a hard time understanding you sometimes,” he continued slowly, careful to choose the right words before concluding, “then I get upset with myself for it, but I shouldn’t take that out on you.”

“It’s not your fault,” I reassured him, wiping the tears from under my chin. I re-positioned myself so I was facing Chris now. The pained look on his face made this more difficult, but there was something so entrancing about how the moonlight coming through the window played with the structured lines of his face. Chris looked soft and pretty, a welcomed contrast to the angry red he’d been earlier. He looked like the Chris I knew and loved. “I’m going to try to communicate better instead of shutting down,” I promised. Chris gave me a tight-lipped smile as he caressed my face, wiping my tears.

“Tell me what’s really been on your mind,” Chris whispered like he was testing the waters with more of an invitation than a demand. I swallowed my reservations, knowing that this was a safer space than the argument we’d had before. Chris was genuinely all ears, I could tell by the patience he exuded.

“You know I love how much you love your work,” I said as I looked him right in the eye, hoping he understood how honest I was. “And I love your friends, too. I love that you have these things that make you so happy… I don’t have a problem sharing you,” I continued, averting my eyes to where my hands sat wringing in my lap.

Chris took notice and held my hands in his, rubbing small circles with his thumbs on my palms. I sighed, knowing he was trying to be understanding, but that meant I had to allow him to be. “I just miss you so much when you’re away and even when you’re here it’s like you aren’t really with me.”

Tears started slipping down my cheeks again. I watched as they dripped down my chin and fell on our hands. “I-I feel like you don’t want to be,” I confessed. Before I finished saying the words, Chris pulled me into another hug. My cheek pressed against his chest, the steady thump of his heart and its movement with each of his breaths bringing me comfort. It reminded me that he was here with me, grounding me back to Earth.

“No, no, no,” Chris whispered, the conviction still evident in his voice. “Couldn’t be farther from the truth,” he reassured me. “I’m sorry I made you feel like that… I didn’t even know you did.” Chris pulled away from the hug, holding me at arm’s length. He tilted my chin up so I looked at him and with the kind of intensity he had in his eyes it was hard to look away.

“I love you more than anything,” Chris declared like he was telling me the sun rises in the east and sets in the west, it was a fact of life. “It makes being away from you a hell of a lot harder than it’s ever been for me before. I guess I was trying to distance myself to make it easier when I’m gone,” Chris sighed, running his fingers through his hair again. “Clearly doesn’t work,” he chuckled. I laughed too, for what felt like the first time in way too long.

“I don’t like when we fight,” I told him, playing with his fingers until they became laced together with mine. “Gee, no ‘I love you too, light of my life?’” Chris poked fun at me. I rolled my eyes, but I wasn’t really annoyed, probably given away by my goofy grin. “You know I do,” I replied, leaning forward to place a kiss on his cheek, already itchy with stubble. When I pulled away, I saw Chris beaming at me with a smile from ear to ear and a light he’d lost before back in his eye. With a voice that was still raspy from his tiredness, Chris said, “I don’t like it either.”

He stood, pulling me by our locked-together hands so I’d follow him. Chris swung our arms between us as he looked down at me with a kindness I’d missed. “Why don’t we get some sleep?” he prompted, tugging us toward the hallway. I walked a little faster so our steps would be in sync, allowing me to cuddle up against his side until we climbed into bed, where we finally fell asleep in each other’s arms.

About: As requested by @i-padfootblack-things, Chris and the reader have a door-slamming, voice-raising, tear-filled kind of fight which ends with sleeping in separate rooms. Well, trying to. After realizing he can’t sleep without her, Chris decides making up would be better than spending the night alone.

Word Count: 3,355

Warnings: fighting, language, you know the drill

Enjoy!
